Award.AwardTitle: Toward a Broader Understanding of Gender Development

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Gender is perhaps the most fundamental social category -both in how we classify and think about other people and in how we define ourselves. Gender plays a central role in human experience throughout the lifespan and especially during childhood. A great deal of research has explored how children begin to understand what gender is and learn which gender typical behaviors, preferences and attitudes are indicated by societal stereotypes of gender roles. Several theories exist to explain the development of gender understanding, from toddlers' ability to identify their own gender to older children's and adolescents' ability to incorporate gender into their own self-concepts. Although the study of gender development has been central to developmental psychology for decades, nearly all research has focused on children who experience "typical" gender development. The goal of this project is investigate how culture, biology, and cognition interact to explain the development of gender understanding by exploring both typical and atypical gender experiences in childhood.

This project is based on the premise that understanding the full range of variability in children's gender experiences is necessary to achieve a complete understanding of gender development. Specifically, this research focuses on three major research questions: (1) What is the role of social input in gender development? (2) Is an understanding that gender is stable across time necessary to develop more complex understandings of gender, such as gender stereotypes?, and (3) Do children with less common gender identities show patterns of gender development similar to those of children with more common gender identities? To answer these questions the researchers will present children with a battery of gender development measures including implicit and explicit measures, relying on both parental and child report, and will compare responses among those with both typical and atypical gender identities. The investigators predict that current models of gender development will not adequately describe gender development across all children, and anticipate that these findings will yield insights into how to revise these theories to better explain gender cognition and behavior in all children.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Gender is a central aspect of one’s identity beginning early in development with most children having a sense of their gender and behaving in line with societal expectations of that identity within the first few years of life. Based on these commonly observed patterns of behaviors, theories of gender development have argued how, why, and when children come to understand and express their gender. Importantly, most of the work contributing to the development of these theories and most of the documented evidence of gender development has focused on gender “typical” children.

The present grant funded the creation of one of the largest databases and studies of gender diverse children, including the largest ever study of young children who are living as a gender that differs from their sex at birth. The study was designed to address three specific questions from existing theoretical work on gender development.

First, this study investigated the role of social input in gender development. The results demonstrated that children receive clear input about the gender they are assumed to be and the social roles of their expected gender early in development. This was true for children who ultimately ended up with gender diverse identities as well as those who show more “typical” gender identity later in life. Our findings demonstrate that children—including gender “typical” and gender diverse children—learn from the culture around them who and what boys and girls “should” play with, that they are aware of stereotypes, and that they recognize gender nonconformity in others. We also see that the children who identify as boys—irrespective of whether they were male at birth or not—on average tend to favor stereotypically masculine toys and clothing and tend to favor playing with boy playmates (and the reverse for children who identify as girls). These results run counter to the idea that a second kind of social input—sex-specific input about how a given child should behave—influences a child’s identity or expression a few years later. For example, a male who transitions to live as a girl after 5 years of being treated as a boy looks similar to a girl of the same age who has always been treated as a girl, suggesting that early sex-specific treatment may not have caused the child to feel like a girl today.

Our second guiding research question came from existing theories that suggested that before a child can hold a strong sense of gender identity, engage in behavior according to stereotypes of that gender, or show strong gender stereotypes, that child must first understand that their gender is stable. Our data suggested that this theoretical claim is likely incorrect. Counter to this theory, many gender diverse children think of their own and others’ gender as changing over time, yet still hold strong gendered preferences, a strong clear sense of gender identity and even gender stereotypes.

Finally, our third major research question was whether gender diverse children show patterns of gender development similar to gender “typical” children. Our findings suggest that they overwhelmingly do. Across many sub-domains of gender—stereotyping, toy preferences, clothing preferences, peer play, implicit and explicit identity—we saw similarity between participants who identified as girls (regardless of whether they were assigned females or assigned males at birth) and we saw similiarty between participants who identified as boys (again, regardless of their sex assignment at birth).

In addition to the original questions this grant aimed to address, this grant funded additional work on childhood gender diversity including work aimed at predicting which gender diverse children are most likely to transition, initial comparisons of children before and after transition in terms of their gender identity and gender-typed preferences, and studies examining children’s perceptions of other children’s gender diversity.

Amongst other highlights, the work supported by this grant resulted in the publication of 12 peer-reviewed papers to date (with several other papers under review or in preparation) and has been discussed in major media outlets. This work was also recognized by the awarding of the 2018 Alan T Waterman Award and a 2018 MacArthur Fellowship for the principal investigator. Finally, 7 graduate students, 2 postdoctoral fellows, 4 staff, and more than two dozen undergraduates were involved in research methods training and gained research experience as part of the conducting the work for this grant.
